I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed debt 
investment in bonds of up to B3,000,000,000 (or its equivalent in United States dollars) out of a 
total issuance of B10 billion to be issued by Energy Absolute Public Company Limited (Energy 
Absolute) for the Energy Absolute Green Bond for Wind Power Project in Thailand. 
 
2.  The project entails the issuance of green bonds to support the long-term financing of 
Energy Absolute’s 260-megawatt (MW) Hanuman wind farm in Thailand through refinancing of 
short-term supplier credit that was used to help complete construction of the project. The Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) will subscribe to the bonds and provide assistance to Energy Absolute 
to ensure that the bonds are recognized as certified climate bonds under the Climate Bonds 
Standard (CBS) of the Climate Bonds Initiative. The bonds will also comply with the International 
Capital Markets Association's Green Bond Principles (GBP) and the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations Green Bond Standards (ASEAN GBS). ADB’s participation is crucial for CBS 
certification of the entire bond issuance, and the project will contribute to the development of the 
green bond market in Thailand and the region. It will be only the third CBS-certified climate bond 
issuance in Thailand and only the second by a Thai energy company. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. The finance sector worldwide is beginning to respond to climate 
change and attempts to mainstream climate mitigation and adaptation into investment decisions. 
Institutional investors and banks have increasingly begun to “decarbonize”1 their portfolios and 
increase “green”2 investments, such as in renewable energy and other areas that contribute to 
climate mitigation and adaptation. This demand has led to a requirement for credible frameworks 
to verify what qualifies as a green investment. Investors need to assure their clients and other 
stakeholders that they are using frameworks that are consistent with delivering science-based 
targets for a low-carbon and climate-resilient economy. This assurance and transparency are 
equally important for project developers and other issuers, because companies and projects with 
significant greenhouse gas emissions can be penalized in the capital markets, whereas climate-
friendly investments may attract new investors and benefit from more favorable financing terms. 
 
4.  Green bonds are innovative financial instruments to promote such efforts, whereby the 
proceeds are used exclusively to finance or refinance, in part or in full, new or existing projects 
with environmental or climate-related benefits. Green bonds provide a mechanism for financing 
investments in green and climate-smart projects that are aligned with the Paris Agreement on 
climate change and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development of the United Nations. The 
“labeled”3 green bond market is growing rapidly and reached an annual issuance amount of 
$167.6 billion in 2018 globally, from just $0.5 billion in 2008. Cumulative issuance since the first 
green bond was issued in 2007 is estimated at $512 billion.4 The GBP and CBS are the two most 
 
1  “Decarbonize” refers to the process of reducing the proportion of investments in greenhouse-gas-intensive sectors, 
technologies, and projects—and correspondingly increasing the proportion of investments in low- or zero-emission 
sectors, technologies, and projects—for a particular investment portfolio or company. 
2  “Green” investments are those with clear environmental benefits. 
3  “Labeled” green bonds are bonds that are labeled as “green” by the issuer because the proceeds are earmarked 
solely for “green” assets. 
4  Climate Bonds Initiative. 2019. Green bonds: The state of the market 2018. London.

2   
widely recognized standards for green bonds based on international best practice.5 Regionally, 
ADB’s Southeast Asia Department provided technical assistance to help the ASEAN Capital 
Markets Forum establish the ASEAN GBS, a standard based on the GBP. The project will 
demonstrate the application of the ASEAN GBS and support an important “One ADB” initiative 
aimed at greening the regional capital markets.6  
 
5.  Against this backdrop of huge untapped markets and opportunities for ADB, green bond 
issuance in ASEAN economies is expected to accelerate. Thailand, in particular, has great 
potential for an active green bond market because it has significant renewable energy resources 
and its bond market is the largest among ASEAN bond markets. The Thai bond market's annual 
issuance of long-term corporate bonds reached a new high of B879 billion in 2018.7 While 
Thailand’s energy production still depends heavily on fossil fuels and renewable energy sources 
are currently contributing only 10%, this is projected to increase to 15%–20% by 2036 under 
Thailand’s Power Development Plan, 2018–2037.8 To date, renewable energy projects have been 
financed mainly by banks. Notwithstanding its growing needs and huge potential, the country’s 
first green bond complying with GBP was only issued in June 2018 by a local bank.

7.  Project description. The project involves a cornerstone investment of up to B3 billion into 
Energy Absolute’s maiden green bond issuance. Energy Absolute is aiming to raise a total of B10 
billion through bond issues with tenors of 3, 5, 7, and 10 years. ADB will invest in the 7-year 
tranche but will facilitate CBS certification of the entire B10 billion bond issuance. Bond proceeds 
will be used to support the long-term financing of the 260 MW Hanuman wind farm in Chaiyaphum 
Province, Thailand. Hanuman is Thailand’s biggest wind farm and reached its commercial 
operation date in April 2019. It has a long-term power purchase agreement (PPA) with the 
Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT). Hanuman will result in annual emission 
reductions of about 200,000 tons of carbon dioxide by 2020. 
 
8.  This will be the second GBP- and CBS-compliant green bond issuance by an energy 
company in Thailand and only the third CBS-compliant green bond issuance in Thailand overall. 
Notwithstanding the accelerating interest among issuers and investors globally, the green bond 
market in Thailand is still in its infancy. Growing demand from potential issuers looking to 
demonstrate their environmental and climate credentials is expected to change the current 
landscape. The project will contribute to the development of the green bond market in Thailand 
by  showcasing  international  best  practice  approaches  to  green  and  climate  bonds 
(i.e., verification and certification) and building on ADB’s momentum gained from working with 
market leaders for climate investment in the region. 
 
9.  Borrower.  Energy  Absolute,  established  in  2006,  is  the  largest  renewable  energy 
company in Thailand by installed capacity. Its main businesses are renewable energy generation 
(solar and wind) and biodiesel production and distribution. The company also plans to expand

green diesel. The major shareholder is Somphote Ahunai, the founder and chief executive officer, 
with a 43.62% stake together with his family members. UBS AG Singapore Branch holds another 
12.64% of shares as custodian and nominee shareholder. It is listed on the Stock Exchange of 
Thailand and as of 19 August 2019 has a market capitalization of B180.9 billion or $5.9 billion.

capacity of 664 MW—four solar power (278 MW) and two wind power (386 MW) plants. All 
renewable energy plants have long-term PPAs with EGAT and the Provincial Electricity Authority 
(PEA). Table 1 summarizes Energy Absolute’s renewable energy portfolio.

11.  The  company  also  manufactures  and  distributes  biodiesel,  purified  glycerin,  and 
byproducts, with a production capacity of 800,000 liters/day. 
 
12.  Energy Absolute is now pursuing further clean energy growth opportunities, such as 
(i) lithium-ion battery energy storage production; (ii) development of new renewable energy 
projects outside of Thailand, and renewable energy projects with integrated battery energy 
storage systems; (iii) electric cars and ferries, including associated charging infrastructure; and 
(iv) "green biodiesel"9 and phase change materials. 
 
13.  In December 2016, Energy Absolute embarked on its energy storage venture by acquiring 
a 35.2% shareholding in Amita Technologies Inc. Amita was established in 2000 and is a 
developer and manufacturer of lithium-ion polymer batteries for use in electric vehicles and 
stationary energy storage. It is listed on the Emerging Stock Board of the Taipei,China stock 
exchange. During 2017–2018, Energy Absolute gradually increased its ownership stake in Amita, 
ending up with a controlling stake of 77.2% in November 2018.  
 
14.  In 2019, Energy Absolute began building a 1 gigawatt-hour energy storage manufacturing 
facility in Thailand’s Eastern Economic Corridor region; production is expected to start in the 
second half of 2020, after a total capital expenditure of B5 billion. The facility is designed to prove 
the  company’s  technological  expertise,  manufacturing  capability  at  scale,  and  product 
performance. Energy Absolute hopes that this first phase of investment into energy storage will 
help attract interest from potential strategic partners to significantly expand the facility.

projects, notably the Phitsanulok solar plant in 2016 (90 MW) and the Hadkanghan wind farm in

company’s revenue  and  profit  is  expected to further  increase  in  2019  and  2020.  Table  2

B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Output 
 
17.  Impacts. The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) diversified energy mix 
through the addition of renewable energy capacity and (ii) use of the bond market as a mechanism 
for raising capital for the private sector to meet larger and more diverse demands for long-term 
investment.  
 
18.  Outcome. The project’s outcome is that the viability of green bonds to sustain private 
sector operation of a renewable energy plant has been demonstrated.

19.   Outputs. The outputs are that a corporate bond by Energy Absolute is successfully 
issued, that the green and climate bond status has been achieved, and that the wind power plant 
is operational.  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
  
20.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which has a target of 75% of ADB operations to support climate change 
mitigation and adaptation by 2030 and a target of $80 billion climate finance from 2019 to 2030.11 
Strategy 2030 also emphasizes the expansion of private sector operations. ADB’s support for the 
project is also in line with its country partnership strategy, 2013–2016 for Thailand12 and its 
country  operations  business  plan,  2018–2020, 13  both  of  which  promote  private  sector 
development and support two core strategic areas for ADB’s focus: infrastructure development 
and environmentally sustainable development. 
 
21.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  project  is 
consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy, which supports wider access to energy through investments 
in energy efficiency and renewable energy projects.14 The project will contribute to ADB’s target 
of $6 billion in annual financing for climate mitigation and adaptation by 2020, and catalyze further 
private sector resources for clean energy investments. 
 
22.  Lessons  from  previous  operations.  ADB’s  private  sector  operations  have  so  far 
supported three landmark green bond issuances in Southeast Asia: the Tiwi and MakBan 
Geothermal Power Green Bonds Project,15 the Thailand Green Bond Project (footnote 9), and the 
AC Energy Green Bond Project (footnote 10). The lessons from these projects is that green bonds 
generate a high level of interest but the process and benefits are still unclear to issuers, arrangers, 
and regional investors. ADB can play a valuable role by not only assisting the certification of the 
bonds  but  also  providing  market  validation,  helping  build  the  profile  of  green  bonds,  and 
encouraging further issuances. 
 
D.  Project Cost and Financing Plan 
 
23.  The proposed project involves the issuance of a B10 billion corporate bond by Energy 
Absolute in multiple tranches with tenors of 3–10 years. Proceeds from the bond will be used for 
the long-term financing of Energy Absolute’s 260 MW Hanuman wind farm in Thailand, including 
the refinancing of short-term supplier credit that was used to help complete construction but does 
not offer a long-term sustainable financing solution. The project reached its commercial operation 
date in April 2019 and has a long-term PPA with EGAT. Table 3 summarizes the sources and 
uses of proceeds from Energy Absolute’s corporate bond issuance.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance

26.  ADB will provide debt financing to Energy Absolute in the form of a corporate bond 
investment of up to B3 billion (or its equivalent in United States dollars) for a total bond issuance 
of  B10  billion.  ADB’s  assistance  will  support  the  long-term financing of  Energy  Absolute’s 
Hanuman wind farm in Thailand. ADB will invest in the 7-year tranche with a bullet repayment. 
ADB will also assist the company with green and climate bond certification for the entire B10 
billion issuance. Energy Absolute’s bonds will be listed with the Thai Bond Market Association 
and will be tradable subject to market conditions. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
27.  ADB’s participation in Energy Absolute’s maiden green bond issuance (which would not 
have been issued as a green bond without ADB’s advice) will ensure that the entire B10 billion 
bond will be certified under the CBS and also complies with the GBP and the ASEAN GBS. These 
instruments and standards are not yet widely recognized in the Thai and ASEAN capital markets, 
and their association with ADB will help make certified green and climate bonds better known in 
the region. ADB’s involvement will also help foster confidence in the benefits of green bonds and 
help promote further investments in renewable energy and other climate-friendly businesses. 
Further, ADB’s participation in the green bond issuance will help support the Hanuman wind farm 
to achieve long-term financial sustainability. Energy Absolute’s ADB-compliant environmental and 
social management system (ESMS) will also provide additional assurance to the market and 
investors of its credibility as an issuer of green bonds.  
 
28.  Green bond program. The project contributes to ADB’s goal to kickstart a program to 
encourage green bond issuance by the private sector, which will help attract commercial investors 
and issuers to this emerging asset class. By leveraging its regional presence, ADB will replicate 
green bond issuance in accordance with international best practice in Thailand and in other 
ASEAN economies, with possible effects on other bond markets in Asia.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
30.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment (category B), involuntary resettlement (category C) and 
indigenous peoples (category C). The policy’s Safeguard Requirement 4 for a general corporate 
finance project, with earmarked subproject, applies. 
 
31.  ADB undertook due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social impacts 
of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. A qualified external expert conducted an audit of the 
corporate ESMS and a project environmental and social audit of the Hanuman wind farm. The 
institutional capacity and commitment of Energy Absolute to manage the project’s social and 
environmental impacts and the measures being implemented are considered adequate. The audit 
did not identify any breach of national environmental or health and safety regulations. The 
company has agreed to implement minor corrective actions under a time-bound corrective action 
plan, including refining the corporate ESMS specifically for the Hanuman wind farm.

8   
32.  Environment. The project is not located in local conservation or protected areas, or areas 
of high conservation value. No forest land is involved in the right of way of the transmission 
corridor used by the project. The initial environmental examination’s avifauna survey results, 
analysis of available secondary data, and consultations with relevant stakeholders indicate that 
the project falls into a low-bird-activity area and has low intensity with regard to migration routes 
of large-bodied birds. 17 CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
33.  Social. The project and its associated facilities are on government land (Sor Por Kor land) 
leased to the company for 27 years. The land was held under an agricultural lease by local farmers 
and  was  later  transferred  in  the  name  of  the  company.  CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION 
DELETED. No impacts on indigenous people are envisaged on account of the project. 
 
34.  Other social dimensions. The project is classified as having no gender elements.18 
Energy  Absolute  will  (i)  apply  ADB's  prohibited  investment  activities  list,  (ii)  ensure  that 
investments using ADB funds comply with the Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by national 
laws and regulations; and (iii) establish and maintain an appropriate ESMS satisfactory to ADB 
before disbursement. The ESMS sets out requirements, as applicable, for compliance with 
national labor laws and measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor 
standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001).19 The ESMS will also contain 
requirements, as applicable, for information disclosure and consultation with affected people in 
line with ADB standards. Energy Absolute will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its investments’ 
compliance with such laws, and (ii) the measures taken.20 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
 
35.  Energy Absolute was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will

metadata.Subject:
The project entails the issuance of green bonds to support the long-term financing ofEnergy Absolute’s 260-megawatt (MW) Hanuman wind farm in Thailand through refinancing ofshort-term supplier credit that was used to help complete construction of the project.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated September 2019 is provided for the ADB project 53255-001 in Thailand.
